items.title: Cervical cancer rates show a 'concerning plateau,' according to new Canadian Cancer Society data
items.summary_auto: After decades of decline, rates of cervical cancer within Canada have plateaued, according to the Canadian Cancer Society — a troubling trend for some experts, given that the type of cancer is preventable.

items.title: Christian group sues Quebec City for cancelling MAGA-affiliated musician's summer concert
items.summary_auto: The Christian group is demanding a refund of $2,609.93 — the cost of the rental space — as well as $5,000 for unconstitutional and unjustified infringements of rights after Quebec City terminated the contract of MAGA-affiliated musician Sean Feucht.

items.title: UN approves U.S. plan authorizing an international stabilization force in Gaza
items.summary_auto: The UN Security Council on Monday approved a U.S. plan for Gaza that authorizes an international stabilization force to provide security in the devastated territory and envisions a possible future path to an independent Palestinian state.

items.title: 25 girls abducted from high school in Nigeria
items.summary_auto: Gunmen attacked a high school in northwestern Nigeria before dawn on Monday, taking 25 schoolgirls and killing at least one staffer, authorities said of the latest abduction of students in the region.

items.title: FEMA acting chief out after just 6 months at helm of agency
items.summary_auto: The acting chief of the U.S. Federal Emergency Management Agency left his job Monday after just six months, according to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the latest disruption in a year of mass staff departures, program cuts and policy upheaval at the agency charged with managing federal disaster response.

items.title: 'Evidence of misconduct' in federal investigation of ex-FBI head James Comey, judge finds
items.summary_auto: A U.S. judge found on  Monday there is evidence of misconduct in how a federal prosecutor closely aligned with President Donald Trump secured criminal charges against James Comey. He also ordered that grand jury materials be turned over to the former FBI chief's defence lawyers.

items.title: The Giller Prize will be announced Monday night. Here are the 5 finalists
YouTuber-turned-boxer Jake Paul to fight two-time world champion Anthony Joshua
items.summary_auto: YouTuber-turned-boxer Jake Paul will fight recent world heavyweight champion Anthony Joshua in a professional bout on Dec. 19. The heavyweight bout, which will consist of eight three-minute rounds, will take place at Kaseya Center in Miami and will be streamed live on Netflix.

items.title: Beloved video app Vine is back, but says no thanks to AI slop
items.summary_auto: Evan Henshaw-Plath is rebooting the app Vine under the name Divine, with the support of Twitter founder Jack Dorsey. The effort aims to combat AI slop by banning any content flagged as AI-generated.

items.title: Poland says explosive device detonated on train route between Warsaw and Ukraine border
items.summary_auto: Poland's Prime Minister Donald Tusk said Monday that an explosion on a section of railway line used for deliveries to Ukraine was an "unprecedented act of sabotage."

items.title: Creator of AI actor Tilly Norwood announces AI-assisted History Channel series
items.summary_auto: The production company behind controversial AI "actor" Tilly Norwood has announced plans with History Channel in the Netherlands for a new AI-assisted historical travel series. Streets of the Past is a 10-part program that will see historian and author Corjan Mol travel to different Dutch sights, which will then be made to appear as they did during various historical periods.

items.title: Saskatoon mom hopes children's book about daughter who died of cancer will help others
items.summary_auto: A Saskatoon mom is hoping to help children with cancer by telling the story of her daughter who died last spring from an aggressive form of leukemia.

items.title: Canada’s curlers become 1st team announced for 2026 Paralympic Winter Games
items.summary_auto: The first Canadian team for the Paralympics Winter Games in Milan Cortina is all set as five wheelchair curlers were nominated on Monday, the Canadian Paralympic Committee and Curling Canada announced.

items.title: Toronto raises Palestinian flag at city hall, joining other cities across Canada
items.summary_auto: The Palestinian flag is flying over Toronto city hall Monday after similar moves by other Canadian cities.

items.title: Annual home sales fall in October as CREA expects lower rates to boost market in 2026
items.summary_auto: The Canadian Real Estate Association says the number of residential properties that changed hands in October was lower compared to a year ago, as prices also fell.

items.title: 3 teens killed in crash near Hanover, Ont., remembered for joy they brought others
items.summary_auto: A week ago, three teenagers were killed in a car crash after leaving a Remembrance Day ceremony at their high school in Hanover, Ont. As a fourth remains in hospital, those who knew the three who died are remembering them as selfless and happy young people whose lives were cut short too soon.

items.title: Systematic violence, denial of medical care contributed to Palestinian deaths in Israeli custody: report
items.summary_auto: The number of Palestinians dying in Israeli custody surged to nearly 100 people since the start of the war in Gaza, according to a report published Monday by a human rights group that says systematic violence and denial of medical care at prisons and detention centers contributed to many of the deaths it examined.

items.title: 2 people facing dozens of charges after hundreds of thefts at GTA mausoleums, cemeteries
items.summary_auto: A man and a woman have been arrested after allegedly committing over 300 thefts at mausoleums and cemeteries across the Greater Toronto Area (GTA), said the Halton Regional Police Service.

items.title: TD Bank settles human rights complaint by Muslim-Indigenous man
items.summary_auto: A human rights complaint in B.C. has been settled between TD Bank and a Muslim-Indigenous man who said a Surrey branch teller denied him service and called the police on him when he tried to open a bank account.

items.title: MGK thrills football fans during 112th Grey Cup halftime show in Winnipeg
items.summary_auto: American rapper and singer-songwriter MGK delivered an energetic performance at Winnipeg’s Princess Auto Stadium during the Grey Cup halftime show on Sunday.

items.title: Inflation rate ticks down to 2.2% in October, mostly due to falling gas prices
items.summary_auto: Canada's inflation rated edged down to 2.2 per cent in October, largely due to gas prices falling at a faster pace, Statistics Canada said on Monday.

items.title: Dozens of religious pilgrims from India feared dead in Saudi bus accident
items.summary_auto: Dozens of Indian pilgrims are feared dead after a bus was in collision with a diesel tanker on Monday near the holy city of Medina in Saudi Arabia, Indian officials said.

items.title: Pediatricians warn application of Bill 2 could leave many children undiagnosed
items.summary_auto: As Quebec physicians continue to oppose the CAQ government’s controversial law that ties a part of doctors' pay to performance indicators, pediatricians argue that the new vulnerability classification in the law will worsen access to care for the province’s youngest patients.

items.title: Christmas presents, in this economy? How some people are shifting their spending
Fast cars and easy money: Insurance agents penalized for role in luxury car 'grey market'
items.summary_auto: More than six years after a provincial report into money laundering warned about the rise of a so-called "grey market" exporting Canadian luxury cars to China, many of the insurance agents who processed paperwork enabling the shadowy deals are facing sanctions.

items.title: Alberta doctors call for regular access to vaccines in children's hospitals to combat low immunization rates
items.summary_auto: Some Alberta pediatricians say they've got an idea to help improve routine childhood vaccination rates, but they're facing roadblocks. The doctors want the shots, including measles and whooping cough vaccines, made routinely available in pediatric hospitals.

items.title: In reversal, Trump urges Republicans to vote to release Epstein files
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump on Sunday urged his fellow Republicans in the House of Representatives to vote for the release of files related to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, after weeks of railing against the Democrats' desire to pass the Epstein Transparency Act.

items.title: Bangladesh's ousted PM Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death for student crackdown
items.summary_auto: A Bangladesh war crimes court sentenced ousted prime minister Sheikh Hasina to death on Monday, concluding a months-long trial that found her guilty of ordering a deadly crackdown on a student-led uprising last year.

items.title: Rogers clients complain of customer service nightmare, spending hours on hold to resolve simple issues
items.summary_auto: Rogers customers say they’re furious about what they say is a lack of customer service — spending hours and hours trying to cancel services or fix bills — as workers who handled Rogers customer service calls get laid off. Experts point to a lack of competition in the industry and few regulatory protections as the culprit.

items.title: Illicit crypto-to-cash deals are unlocking new ways to launder money in Canada
items.summary_auto: Canada has long had a problem with dirty money in its economy, whether in banking or real estate, but the advent of anonymous crypto-to-cash services has opened new frontiers for potential laundering and illicit finance, experts say.

items.title: Budget 2025 slashes Canada Student Grants, experts warn
items.summary_auto: Some experts are concerned that post-secondary students will have access to less money through the Canada Student Grant (CSG), based on a line item buried in Budget 2025.

items.title: Federal refugee employment program faces 'extremely long, ballooning wait times'
items.summary_auto: Instead of months, a federal program is now taking years to process the applications of skilled refugees living overseas and have a job waiting for them in Canada.

items.title: Back on earth, astronaut Chris Hadfield writes about space
items.summary_auto: The Canadian author discussed his book, Final Orbit, on Bookends with Mattea Roach.
